body: - CFLAG gnu99 was changed to c99. - CXXFLAG c++98 was changed to c++11. - CFLAG -pedantic-errors was added so that non-ISO C now throws errors. - _XOPEN_SOURCE feature test macro added and set to 600 to expose SUSv3 and c99 definitions in modules that required them. - Fixed tests (and bootstrap daemon logging) that were failing due to the altered build flags. - Avoid string suffix misinterpretation; explicit narrowing conversion. - Misc. additions to .gitignore to make sure build artifacts don't wind up in version control. I didn't try running the tests, but everything seems to build just fine now. If someone could test for me, I'd really appreciate it. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297)

comment_regular_data.body: Run `other/astyle/format-source`.

> Warning suppressions were removed

Indeed, and now it no longer compiles. Please add them back.

*Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297)*
<!-- Sent from Reviewable.io -->

> these aren't make files, they're generated files

I know that, but does it really matter? What heading do you want me to put them under?

> why did you drop -pedantic

Because I added *-pedantic-errors*, which does the same and more.

> what are you including strings.h for?

Because that's where *strncasecmp()* is declared

> why is this better?

Because *d_type* is a BSD-ism, and the point of this PR is to increase portability.


There's a little bit more for me to fix up to get it to build, pls no mergerino por favorino. I'll let you guys know when it's good.
@GrayHatter good now?

Review status: 1 of 23 files reviewed at latest revision, 8 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed. --- *[other/bootstrap_daemon/src/log.c, line 119 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297#-KYIxBLP0eYajxNqFLEV:-KYKhpWN7Dd4gpAv2s_e:bednm4t) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a017f20e6aabead751ac2c8b62a67a6d45537e2d/other/bootstrap_daemon/src/log.c#L119)):*
Previously, iphydf wrote…
Ah. I see now. Don't use `fprintf` with a user-specified format string.
The "don't use user-specified format string" is supposed to protect against the [format string attacks](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Format_string_attack), isn't it? But all the format strings that we pass to the logging procedure are not really user-specified, they are compile-time specified, the actual user of tox-bootstrapd binary can't alter the format, neither the format string comes from other potentially insecure input sources such as the network. It is user-specified only from the point of the view of the logging module, as in "the rest of the code is the user". Even if we ignore the fact that the string is not really user-specified and for a second assume that it is (it's not though), now we use `vsnprintf` with as such "user-specified format string", so how is that an improvement? Am I missing something? --- *[testing/tox_sync.c, line 319 at r4](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297#-KYKjzej3GBjqZCX2hgI:-KYKjzej8f6naaah86DJ:be2v7d9) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/f18a53caab7a8bc82944aeebb22670e62dd3293c/testing/tox_sync.c#L319)):* > ```C > char filepath[strlen(path) + strlen(dir->d_name)]; > memcpy(filepath, path, strlen(path)); > memcpy(filepath + strlen(path), dir->d_name, strlen(dir->d_name) + 1); > ``` So, you allocate a buffer of size X+Y but you write X+Y+1 into it? --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297)*

@iphydf There is a misunderstanding here. You were commented on zero-one's change that used `fprintf(level_stdout(level), buf)`, while I was trying to understand why was log.c modified in the first place, assuming that it was modified because of some issue with a user-specified format string. I later read IRC log and found that log.c was modified because `vsyslog()` is not portable. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297)*

You were commented on zero-one's change that used `fprintf(level_stdout(level), buf)`, while I was trying to understand why was log.c modified in the first place, assuming that it was modified because of some issue with a user-specified format string. I later read IRC log and found that log.c was modified because `vsyslog()` is not portable.
@zero-one could you move the code which `vsnprintf()`'s `format` and `args` inside the `log_syslog()` function which you have deleted? And also bring back the `log_stdout()` function. I'm trying to keep syslog and stdout log backends separate. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297)*

># Error on non-ISO C

Error? It either needs its own option or be put inside the existing

>if(ERROR_ON_WARNING)

Rationale: builds for users should error.

It's somewhat debatable though, as I'm not sure how likely it's to error for a user but not for us. You explicitly specify to use C99 standard and I wouldn't really expect different compiler versions to exhibit different behavior for C99's `-pedantic-errors`.

Review status: 26 of 27 files reviewed at latest revision, 6 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed. --- *[CMakeLists.txt, line 65 at r5](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297#-KYh7X-mmQ_EMOgTHtq_:-KZCivnIpbaIyiIMbfYQ:b-w5eip7) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/5c795f0b4bd0dd863443fb2c00be9941480ad843/CMakeLists.txt#L65)):*
Previously, Zer0-One (David Zero) wrote…
non-issue, afaik.
I don't have much of an opinion on this. If you make it `-pedantic` and then enable `ERROR_ON_WARNING`, it's the same thing. This `-pedantic-errors` flag is basically `-pedantic -Werror=pedantic`. We can keep it like this, and if we ever run into the situation where this flag causes errors on a user's compiler (or jenkins) but not on our travis build, it stops being a non-issue, and we'll change it to `-pedantic` then. On the other hand: why do you want to default to erroring on non-ISO C? Given that our travis builds already errors on warnings, this seems to add no value. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297)*

Review status: 26 of 27 files reviewed at latest revision, 6 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed. --- *[other/bootstrap_daemon/src/log.c, line 119 at r3](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297#-KYIxBLP0eYajxNqFLEV:-KZCk0f27YUkqS3gMU48:b23521o) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/a017f20e6aabead751ac2c8b62a67a6d45537e2d/other/bootstrap_daemon/src/log.c#L119)):*
Previously, nurupo wrote…
Thanks!
I don't really understand this though. You're replacing one line with another line that calls a function containing the former line, ends up being 500% more code. The part I don't understand is the "keeping backends separate". You still have explicit knowledge of every backend in this function. What is the advantage of having `my_foo(...)` instead of `foo(...)`? --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297)*

done --- Review status: 14 of 27 files reviewed at latest revision, 6 unresolved discussions. --- *[CMakeLists.txt, line 65 at r5](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297#-KYh7X-mmQ_EMOgTHtq_:-KZGhDCRZRAdaHTK0xVV:bqxkkuh) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/5c795f0b4bd0dd863443fb2c00be9941480ad843/CMakeLists.txt#L65)):*
Previously, iphydf wrote…
I don't have much of an opinion on this. If you make it `-pedantic` and then enable `ERROR_ON_WARNING`, it's the same thing. This `-pedantic-errors` flag is basically `-pedantic -Werror=pedantic`. We can keep it like this, and if we ever run into the situation where this flag causes errors on a user's compiler (or jenkins) but not on our travis build, it stops being a non-issue, and we'll change it to `-pedantic` then. On the other hand: why do you want to default to erroring on non-ISO C? Given that our travis builds already errors on warnings, this seems to add no value.
It's more immediately noticeable by a dev who has added non-portable code. i.e, they know right after they run `make` instead of after they've submitted the PR and gone through the Travis logs. --- *[other/bootstrap_daemon/src/log.c, line 88 at r6](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297#-KZB-y4TwWocKw0pHhh8:-KZaMEkfLoGzVnNbCOtS:bb7f2mf) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/52d06a68676bb95f1d792113bbfe9fbf330cfe5f/other/bootstrap_daemon/src/log.c#L88)):*

Check for negative return value that is returned on error: add both an assert and an if condition that would just return silently.

*[other/bootstrap_daemon/src/log.c, line 88 at r8](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/297#-K_7SoYoMfVk1Naz_uH1:-K_7SoYoMfVk1Naz_uH2:bvl26x6) ([raw file](https://github.com/toktok/c-toxcore/blob/0d12a4b325b3e9878f4a7fbbbfb0453f398ec180/other/bootstrap_daemon/src/log.c#L88)):*
> ```C
> 
>     va_copy(args2, args);
>     int size = vsnprintf(NULL, 0, format, args2) + 1;
> ```

I just noticed this `+ 1` at the end. It breaks the checks we do in `assert` and `if` below, since `vsnprintf()` returns a negative when it errors, which might be `-1`. Also, I don't see any need in having `+1` in there technically speaking, as you already account for `vsnprintf()` not counting null byte by having `+1` in `buf[size + 1]` below.

I think this `+1` should be removed.

---

commit.message:
Portability fixes

- CFLAG gnu99 was changed to c99.
- CXXFLAG c++98 was changed to c++11.
- CFLAG -pedantic-errors was added so that non-ISO C now throws errors.
- _XOPEN_SOURCE feature test macro added and set to 600 to expose SUSv3
  and c99 definitions in modules that required them.
- Fixed tests (and bootstrap daemon logging) that were failing due to
  the altered build flags.
- Avoid string suffix misinterpretation; explicit narrowing conversion.
- Misc. additions to .gitignore to make sure build artifacts don't wind
  up in version control.

title: Portability fixes
